There is a lot of misinformation out there about the coronavirus. Some of it is based on misinformation and misinformation from the mainstream media.  For example, the Washington Post has a page dedicated to debunking this misinformation, but it doesn't mention any specific facts about this virus, other than the fact that it's been around for a long time and can be transmitted from person to person (i.e. people can catch it from someone who has it).  So, I'm asking this question because I think it would be very helpful to have some context for what's actually going on in this country right now, and what the current situation is like in other countries, so that we can make informed decisions about how to respond to this pandemic and how we're going to deal with it in a way that protects our health and the lives of those we care about most, including our elderly and those who are most at risk of serious illness or death. I'd like to know what specific information we should be providing to our healthcare providers regarding this, in particular regarding the use of masks and gowns, as a means of protecting ourselves and our loved ones from potentially infected people, especially those with underlying health conditions, such as heart disease, diabetes, cancer, lung disease or other chronic conditions. What specific guidelines should we be using to ensure that people are properly dressed, how long they can stay in their gown and gloves, what kind of hand hygiene products they should use, etc.?  I know that there are a number of different government and non-governmental organizations that are working on these kinds of issues, e.g. the World Health Organization, WHO, World Organisation for Animal Health (OIE), WHO Global Programme on Coronaviruses and Disease (GOPO), the International Committee on Disease Prevention and Control (ICDC), and many more. But I don't think there's a single organization that has the expertise or the capacity to objectively assess and objectively evaluate the risks and benefits of wearing and using masks, whether they are effective in preventing or treating COVID-2019, or whether their use is associated with better outcomes for people living with HIV and other HIV-affected people in developing countries or countries where the disease is most likely to be most severe. In particular, there have been no systematic reviews or meta-analyses on the effectiveness of any of these approaches, nor have there been peer-reviewed articles or clinical trials assessing the safety and efficacy of such interventions in countries with or without a confirmed case fatality rate of HIV/AIDS, malaria, tuberculosis, HIV, pneumonias, adenovirus, pneumonia, acute myelitis, chronic respiratory disease (COSE), malaria-associated respiratory syndrome (MERS-CoV-2) or malaria–associated viral pneumonia (PAM) as potential prevention or treatment strategies. I am a PhD student in the Department of Mechanical Engineering at the University of Waterloo. My advisor is a professor of mechanical engineering. She is currently working on a project to develop a robot that can perform tasks such as cleaning and disinfecting surfaces. Her robot is based on the SARS-CoV-2 virus, which was first identified in 2003. It has a high-level human-to-human transmission mechanism and is capable of reproducing itself in a variety of environments, including indoor and outdoor environments.  The robot has been engineered to be able to perform these tasks in environments that are conducive to its ability to thrive in, for example, a laboratory setting, where it can be used as a resource for research, as well as as in research settings where the human intervention is required to protect the health and well-being of its users.


I am interested in learning more about the biology of this virus and how it spreads. What are the challenges and challenges of designing and developing a vaccine for this new virus?  I would love to hear your thoughts on these issues. Please let me know if you have any ideas for future research projects that could potentially benefit the research community in this area. Thanks in advance!  
Edit: I have now received a reply from the advisor, who is very clear that she is not aware of any research project that would benefit from using a human as the primary source of vaccine candidate. I do not want to make a big deal of a fuss about this, I just wanted to clarify a few points. First of all, she does not know that there are currently any human clinical trials underway for the vaccine. Secondly, the current pandemic is being led by China, so it would be very difficult for her to predict exactly how the virus would spread, given that it is thought to originate from bats and not from humans. In addition, there is no evidence that bats or other animals have been infected, nor have they been exposed to it. Furthermore, bats are not the main reservoir reservoir of virus for which vaccines are developed. Therefore, any vaccine development would need to take into account the bats' unique ecology, their unique biology and the unique challenges they face in their daily lives. This is, of course, subject to many other factors, e.g. how well they are adapted to live in different environments and their immune responses to pathogens. However, this is an extremely challenging and challenging field and one that requires a lot of research. So, my question is: how can I best support my advisor in her efforts to understand this and to help her understand how this could be achieved? I hope that this will be of interest to you, in particular if it helps to answer your own questions about how to proceed with research on this particular virus. Also, if this answer is helpful for you in your field, please share it with me so that I may incorporate it into my own research efforts. If not, then please send me a message and I will try my best to reply as quickly as possible to any of your questions. Thank you very much! Coronaviruses are a large family of viruses that cause respiratory infections ranging from the common cold to severe acute respiratory illness (SARS-CoV-2). The virus that causes COVID-19 is named for the Latin word for "corona", which means "to die". The name of the virus is also a reference to the fact that it is a common disease to have multiple names for different viruses. For example, in the case of SARS, the first name is Corona, while the second is Rhinovirus.

Why is it called the "Corona virus" when there are so many other viruses? Is it because it has a different type of epithelium called a rhinolophore, or does it mean something else entirely? I don't know, but it sounds like a good name for a virus to refer to a specific part of your body that is affected by the disease.

Shopping for groceries is a great way to reduce your risk of catching COVID-19. However, there are many things you can do to help protect yourself and your family.

You can:
Regularly clean your hands and cover your coughs and sneezes with the bend of elbow or tissue when you are outside
Avoid touching your face or hands with unwashed hands
Wear a face mask if you have a fever, cough or difficulty breathing
Cover your mouth and nose with a tissue and then wrap your arms around your throat or nose
Practice breathing techniques such as breathing in through your nose or mouth
Take a regular swab every 15 minutes or so to look for any signs of infection

But, these models are very difficult to use because they assume very large sample sizes, which means that they are not accurate enough to give a good estimate of future trends.
